data.title: Opening file from explorer opens new Atom window
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Whenever I open a file from a folder in Windows, it opens new window of Atom instead of new tab within already opened window. This started to happen after latest update. One week before it was working well. I mean, when I open file in project panel on the left side, it works good. But in explorer, or when I want to fast-edit file from FTP with FileZilla, it opens new window.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom and do some work.
2. Now open any file from explorer
3. New Atom window will open

**Expected behavior:** It should open a file in new tab

**Actual behavior:** Ton of windows
### Versions

Atom     : 1.10.0
Electron : 0.37.8
Chrome : 49.0.2623.75
Node     : 5.10.0
OS         : Windows 10, 64-bit

data.title: Add an option to disable smooth scrolling
data.body: I was using Atom 1.8.8 previously which did not include smooth scrolling. Today I updated to 1.10 which has smooth scrolling enabled by default, but I cannot figure out how to turn it off. There do not seem to any plugins or tutorials on how to disable it either. In Chrome, the user can open chrome://flags and manually disable it, but I could not figure out how. [This post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-access-chrome-flags-in-electron/16470/6) gives me a few hints, but not much else unfortunately.

data.body: when saving files, its automatic adding new line.

data.title: Trend Micro slows Atom startup considerably after Atom update
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? **More generic issue reported at #2654**

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom starts slowly when Trend Micro Maximum Security Antivirus is enabled. This happened only after an upgrade fom 1.9.0 to 1.10.0. Even with the atom folder added to the exception list, the problem still occurs.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start up atom with the following script:

``` python
from time import perf_counter# Python timer function
import os

begin=perf_counter()# Start timer
os.system("atom --safe --profile-startup")# Exits when cmd prompt would usually return
end=perf_counter()# End timer
print("Time",end-begin)# Print time delta
```
1. Save the startup profile
2. Open a `timecop` view and screenshot times
3. Copy the printed time

These are logs collected with `--profile-startup` (renamed to have .txt extension):

[CPU-20160903T140657_antivirus_safe.cpuprofile.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/453636/CPU-20160903T140657_antivirus_safe.cpuprofile.txt)

[CPU-20160903T140306_noantivirus_safe.cpuprofile.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/453635/CPU-20160903T140306_noantivirus_safe.cpuprofile.txt)

These are the screenshots with `timecop`:

**Antivirus:**
![atom_antivirus](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14067959/18227639/7ef48a18-71e0-11e6-99d6-251c5b0a4602.PNG)

**No Antivirus:**
![atom_no_antivirus](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14067959/18227645/8ccac36e-71e0-11e6-8662-6436afae5324.PNG)

These are the times returned by the python script (precise to at least a microsecond):

**Antivirus:** 11.949334730807175
**No Antivirus:** 0.2880780427960264

The Atom process didn't even appear in Task Manager for over 10 seconds (if this helps to pin down the cause).

**Expected behavior:** Fast startup

**Actual behavior:** Startup that takes over 10 seconds
### Versions

Windows 10

```
> atom --version

Atom    : 1.10.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
> apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 3.5.2
git 2.5.3.windows.1
visual studio 2013
```

Perhaps the discrepancy in the `node` versions may have something to do with this as well?

data.title: Mouse scroll misbehaves on Linux after alt-tabbing
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

With a window that partially or fully overlaps Atom's window, if that other window is on top and mouse scrolls are made on the part that overlaps Atom, and then one alt-tabs directly back into Atom and attempts to mouse scroll, it "re-plays" all those scrolls made and applies them along with the mouse scroll actually made.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom, preferably with a very long file, open around the middle, to make it more obvious
2. Open any other window and place it on top of Atom. It doesn't actually matter if it has any scrollable content at all.
3. Focus the other window and mouse scroll a lot over it in the same direction. Say, downwards.
4. Alt-tab to Atom. Make sure not to move your mouse, at least not outside the boundaries of the Atom window.
5. Perform a single mouse scroll "click" in the opposite direction, i.e. if you scrolled downwards a lot in step 3, now scroll upwards once
6. Repeat steps 3 to 5, swap directions around a bit

**Expected behavior:** The content scrolls up and down accordingly, only as far as I expect it to

**Actual behavior:** The first time you do step 6, no scrolls happen. Afterwards, the content scrolls by as much as you've scrolled in step 3, and in that direction, even though in step 6 you scrolled once.

[I've recorded a video demonstrating this](https://my.mixtape.moe/nrpgkw.webm). Note that each time I alt-tab to Atom, I do a single scroll 'click', but the content jumps by a lot each time.

Switching to Atom by any method other than alt-tab (i.e. clicking on the Atom window to raise it, clicking the icon on any dock or taskbar, etc.) does not trigger this behaviour. Only alt-tabbing, and only if the mouse cursor doesn't leave the boundaries of the Atom window right before or after alt-tabbing.

Atom 1.9 also had the same problem, which I worked around by downgrading electron to 0.36.12 at compile time. This workaround makes Atom 1.10 fail to start (unrelated issue), so downgrading electron is no longer an option for me.

[This Chrome issue](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=608246) that I've also reported is probably related, but now it happens even without xf86-xinput-libinput or even libinput installed.
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.10.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

Atom installed from this [AUR package](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/atom-editor/)
OS: Arch Linux 64-bit, fully up-to-date.

data.title: Compile native modules on Travis using clang-3.3
data.body:
Fixes #12587.

All the native modules we ship with Atom are compiled by dynamically linking the libstdc++ library. Using gcc (and g++) > 4.6 to compile them, however, requires a newer version of that library, which is not installed by default on Ubuntu Precise (Travis' default image) and thus causes all the third-party packages built via Travis to fail when using Atom 1.11-beta.

By using clang-3.3 we can keep backwards compatibility with previous versions of libstdc++ and still be able to compile C++11 code (which is mandatory for Node >= 4).

data.title: Help > Documentation takes you to https://flight-manual.atom.io/, which returns a "Privacy error"
data.body:
### Description

Help > Documentation takes you to https://flight-manual.atom.io/, which returns a "Privacy error".
### Steps to Reproduce
1. In the menu bar, go to Help
2. Click on Documentation

**Expected behavior:** https://flight-manual.atom.io/ should open in your browser without any issues.

**Actual behavior:** "Privacy error", specifically **NET::ERR_CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID**, is returned.

![screen shot 2016-09-01 at 10 49 27 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1141338/18178295/a1923002-7032-11e6-93e6-7a9b191e4276.png)
### Versions

Atom: 1.10.0
OS: Mac OS 10.11.6, Windows 10
Browser: Chrome (Version 52.0.2743.116 (64-bit)), Safari (Version 9.1.2 (11601.7.7))

data.title: Data loss on save over SSHFS. Also, NULLs appended.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [*] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [*] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [*] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [*] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [*] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [*] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When I work on a project over a network share (SSHFS; I haven't tried other ways of doing network share mounts), saving files sometimes results in deletion of portions of the file I'm working on (deletions don't seem to care about position relative to newlines), and appends NULL characters to the end (before the trailing newline if there is one).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create an SSHFS mount to get at a project.
2. Start work on a project.
3. Make changes.
4. Save changes.

Note this probably happens with around 1/4-1/3 of my days when I start work.

**Expected behavior:**

Files should be saved reliably, without random deletions, and without random insertions of NULL characters.

**Actual behavior:**

See description
### Versions

$ atom --version
Atom : 1.10.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome : 49.0.2623.75
Node : 5.10.0

I'm on OS X 10.11.6.

data.title: Remove `height: 100%` from atom-text-editor elements
data.body: Originally, editors with autoHeight set to false had an inline style of 100%. We attempted to retain this behavior while allowing CSS to change the height by applying this styling via a global CSS rule instead: unfortunately, however, this applies to non autoHeight editors as well because due to our deprecated autoHeight detection routine, the height of these editors must be assigned on an internal element and therefore does not override the 100% styling from the stylesheet.

data.title: Let atom-pane-resize-hanle inherit correct height (fix #7446)
data.body:
This patch fixes `<atom-pane-resize-handle>`(`the handle`) overflow issue introduced in #7446 .

I was thinking of removing `/static/panes.less#L19` 's `z-index: 3`, but it just hide the handle, its height still overflows.

Then I noticed `the handle` uses `height: 100%` to gain height. The overflowed handle, between two `atom-pane-axis.horizontal.pane-row`, should have inherid it's direct parent, but actual it herited a further parent in higher hierachy `atom-pane-axis.horizontal.pane-column`. `atom-pane-axis` does't have a rule let its direct child uses `height: 100%` to gain expected height.

As a result, I set `position: relative` for `atom-pane-axis` to make atom-pane-resize-handle as it's direct child gain correct height.

screenshot with this patch:

![screenshot_20160901_214907](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3102803/18170586/62a53916-7091-11e6-8eb5-d43345e5fd2b.png)

data.title: Wrong package name for beta .deb distribution
data.body:
I have a script that perform the automatic update from both versions (release and beta). Yesterday they got crazy.

The problem is that the last beta release (1.11.0-beta0) commes with `Package: atom` in deb control file.

Previous beta (1.10.0-beta7 - 21f835142289c52a09e8322bdff4948917776065) deb control file:

```
Package: atom-beta
Version: 1.10.0-beta7
...
```

Current beta (1.11.0-beta0 - 538aa945a2fe680ebd39d4789d725421e6158453) deb control file:

```
Package: atom
Version: 1.11.0-beta0-538aa94
...
```

data.title: missing first letter on file operations (cut/copy/rename exc.)
data.body:
Hi there. This is not an Atom bug but one of its dependencies. I open this issue here because I couldn't find the responsible package. 

I also encounter this bug in gulp (3 & 4), glob and a couple of other packages.
### Description

When you use capital 'i'  ( İ ) in directory names on Turkish environments,  first letter of directory vanishes at the end of the operation. 

Ex: When I rename a file like this in Atom (`\project-dir` is the root path of the project folder) `C:\Dev\İpler\project-dir\subdir\file.js` the renaming window opens file as `ubdir\file.js` 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a directory that contains/starts a capital `i` (İ) letter on its path names.
2. Create a sub directory in that directory that going to be a project folder.
3. Open Atom with that path
4. Create a file under sub directory.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git 2.9.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
